Context:
The Culinary Skills program at George Brown College operates from Monday to Friday. Some classes may start as early as 7 a.m., while others may run until 10 p.m. The culinary skills gained through this program are in demand in Toronto's food service industry, which has over 9,000 restaurants, hotel dining rooms, cafes, eateries, clubs, resorts, spas, and catering companies.

Graduates of the program may qualify for direct entry to the second year of George Brown College's Culinary Management diploma program. The required courses in the first semester include "Smart Serve," "Café Production," "Fundamentals of Butchery," "Baking and Pastry for Cooks," "Culinary Foundations," "Culinary Essentials," "Nutrition Fundamentals from a Culinary Perspective," "Theory of Food I," "Sanitation," "Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR," "Culinary Math Essentials," "Communicating Across Contexts," "Science of Sustainability," and several others. The second semester includes courses such as "WHMIS," "Foods of the World," "Culinary Principles," "Culinary Concepts," "Theory of Food II," "Food, Beverage and Labour Cost Control," "Beverage and Service Fundamentals," and "The Sustainable Chef."

Please note that some courses have an asterisk (*) symbol next to them, indicating further information about these courses may be necessary. Also, there is a hybrid course (Food, Beverage and Labour Cost Control) and a weekend course (Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR).

Context:
Program Offered: Culinary Arts or Food Service Fundamentals
Courses: HOSF1297 - The Sustainable Chef, HOST1126 - Career Preparation (seven-week courses)
Placement Test Requirement: COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000
Costs:
- Domestic Tuition: $7,071.00 (for the first two semesters)
- International Tuition: $21,299.00 (for the first two semesters)
Additional Costs: Not provided in the text
Learning Outcomes: A graduate will be able to provide culinary preparation and presentation, apply food science, ensure a well-maintained kitchen environment, promote healthy workspaces and efficient use of resources, support menu development, understand business principles, and use technology. They will also be expected to contribute as a team member, learn continuously, and apply sustainability and ethical food sourcing knowledge.

*Please note that the text does not provide specific details on when the program starts or contact information for the assessment centre.*

Context:
Program starting year: Fall 2023 and Fall 2024
Fees: Subject to change for programs starting in these years
Total costs (tuition, materials, student service, and ancillary fees) for first two semesters of Fall 2023 programs: Amounts listed in the text are not provided.

Additional Costs:
- Small wares: $100–$300
- Books: $400

Semester 1 tuition fees include the cost of a culinary kit, safety shoes, and Chef School uniform. The detailed list of what is contained in the culinary kit can be found on the "George Brown Culinary Kit Detailed List" page.

Financial Assistance: This program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet OSAP eligibility criteria.

Admission Requirements: Applicants require an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, and a Grade 12 English (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English or consider upgrading to achieve the necessary English credits. Meeting the minimum requirements does not guarantee admission to the program, as applicants may be required to have higher grades.

Country-specific admission requirements can be found on the "International Admissions" page.

Health Policy: Students should be aware that various allergens including nuts, dairy and shellfish are routinely used in practical labs. George Brown College is sensitive to religious observances but cannot guarantee products purchased for production and consumption meet all dietary requirements.

Context:
The text provides information on how to apply for admission to George Brown College, contacts for inquiries about domestic and international admissions, financial aid, and specific program (Culinary Skills) inquiries. Here is the extracted information:

- International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
- Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
- For inquiries about domestic admission requirements, deadlines or the admissions process, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit their webpage.
- For inquiries about OSAP, bursaries, scholarships and other financial inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit their webpage.
- For general Chef School inquiries, contact CHCAStudentSupport@georgebrown.ca.
- George Brown College Contact Centre can be contacted at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
- International students can contact recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the International Contact Us page.
- Join Open House Discovery Day to learn more about areas of interest, get a first-hand look at facilities and meet representatives from George Brown College.
- Register for Sacraspice, a charity that delivers cooking workshops to teach young people essential culinary skills founded by Crystal and Celeste Ceres.
- Ontario residents can apply through Ontario Colleges.
- The text mentions the following programs: Culinary Management (H100), Cook Apprentice (H601), Culinary Management (Integrated Learning) (H116), and Culinary Skills (H134).
